title: Data generation
text: get acquainted functionality usage smdi package, package includes simulated example dataset. dataset exemplary low-dimensional electronic health records (EHR) dataset depicting cohort 2,500 lung cancer patients. dataset follows general one-row-per-patient structure, one row stands individual patient columns represent variables.

title: Data generation
text: Let‚Äôs assume interested studying comparative effectiveness two antineoplastic systemic drug treatment regimens (exposure (0/1)) time death due reason outcome (overall survival). anticipated time follow-truncated 5 years. desired strength effectiveness exposure interest defined hazard ratio 1.0, .e.¬†difference overall survival among patients treated exposure interest compared comparator regimen. proportional hazards assumption fulfilled dataset.

title: Data generation
text: assume confounders need specify estimate outcome model. covariates associated probability treatmente initation outcome also predictive exposure just outcome associated exposure outcome, whatsoever. Despite low dimensionality, dataset simulated realistically possible varying strengths associations covariates treatment initiation outcome.

title: Data generation
text: importantly testing functionality package, mentioned confounders just partially observed according missingness mechanisms proportions specified table @ref(overview)) .

title: Data generation
text: get overview dataset, table provides summary different covariate-exposure-outcome-missingness correlations.

title: Data generation
text: first step, create dataset 2,500 patients 12 variables following distributions. following table illustrates odds exposure assignment. Fitting generalized linear model assessing probablity treatment assignment, constellation odds results following simulated distributions depicting propensities treatment initiation (aka propensity scores). Treatment assignment probabilities.
code: set.seed(seed_value)  # start with basic dataframe, covariates and their association with exposure sim_covar <- tibble::tibble(   exposure = rbinom(n = n, size = 1, prob = 0.4),   age_num = rnorm(n, mean = 64 - 7.5*exposure, sd = 13.7),   female_cat = rbinom(n, size = 1, prob = 0.39 - 0.12*exposure),   ecog_cat = rbinom(n, size = 1, prob = 0.63 - 0.08*exposure),   smoking_cat = rbinom(n, size = 1, prob = 0.45 + 0.1*exposure),    physical_cat = rbinom(n, size = 1, prob = 0.35 + 0.15*exposure),   egfr_cat = rbinom(n, size = 1, prob = 0.20 + 0.1*exposure),    alk_cat = rbinom(n, size = 1, prob = 0.03),   pdl1_num = rnorm(n, mean = 30 + 20*exposure, sd = 20.5),   histology_cat = rbinom(n, size = 1, prob = 0.2),   ses_cat = sample(x = c("1_low", "2_middle", "3_high"), size = n, replace = TRUE, prob = c(0.2 , 0.4, 0.4)),   copd_cat = rbinom(n, size = 1, prob = 0.3 + 0.5*smoking_cat)   ) %>%     # bring data in right format   dplyr::mutate(across(ends_with("num"), as.numeric)) %>%    dplyr::mutate(across(ends_with("num"), function(x) round(x, digits = 2))) sim_covar %>%    gtsummary::tbl_summary(by = "exposure") %>%    gtsummary::add_difference() exposure_form <- as.formula(paste("exposure ~ ", paste(colnames(sim_covar %>% dplyr::select(-exposure)), collapse = " + ")))  exposure_fit <- stats::glm(   exposure_form,   data = sim_covar,   family = "binomial"   )  exposure_fit %>%    gtsummary::tbl_regression(exponentiate = T) # compute propensity score exposure_plot <- sim_covar %>%    dplyr::mutate(ps = fitted(exposure_fit))  # plot density exposure_plot %>%    ggplot2::ggplot(ggplot2::aes(x = ps, fill = factor(exposure))) +   ggplot2::geom_density(alpha = .5) +   ggplot2::theme_bw() +   ggplot2::labs(     x = "Pr(exposure)",     y = "Density",     fill = "Exposed"   )

title: Data generation
text: Next, simulate time--event outcome overall survival. , simsurv package used following assumptions: Parametric event times follow Weibull distribution Max event times: 5 years follow-Event times depend (time-fixed/baseline) covariate effects listed table beta coefficients outcome model defined following
code: betas_os <- c(   exposure = log(1),   age_num = log(1.05),   female_cat = log(0.94),   ecog_cat = log(1.25),   smoking_cat = log(1.3),   physical_cat = log(0.79),   egfr_cat = log(0.5),   alk_cat = log(0.91),   pdl1_num = log(0.72),   histology_cat = log(1.15)   )  betas_os %>%    as.data.frame() %>%    dplyr::transmute(logHR = round(`.`, 2)) %>%    tibble::rownames_to_column(var = "Covariate") %>%    dplyr::mutate(HR = round(exp(logHR), 2)) %>%    gt::gt() set.seed(420)  sim_df <- sim_covar %>% dplyr::bind_cols(   simsurv::simsurv(     dist = "weibull",     lambdas = 5,     gammas = 3.5,     betas = betas_os,     x = sim_covar,     maxt = 60 # in months     )   ) %>%    dplyr::select(-id)

previous_headings: Simulation of covariates and exposure > Simulate time-to-event
title: Data generation
text: simulation resulted following crude Kaplan-Meier estimates 1-yr 5-yr survival. Unadjusted estimates belown shown overall exposure overall survival. Given, true exposure effect null, crude model severely biased can see even clearly crude Kaplan-Meier curve.
code: km_overall <- survival::survfit(survival::Surv(eventtime, status) ~ 1, data = sim_df) km_exposure <- survival::survfit(survival::Surv(eventtime, status) ~ exposure, data = sim_df)  gtsummary::tbl_survfit(   list(km_overall, km_exposure),   times = c(12, 60),   label_header = "**{time} Months**"   ) km_exposure <- survival::survfit(survival::Surv(eventtime, status) ~ exposure, data = sim_df)  survminer::ggsurvplot(   km_exposure,    data = sim_df,   conf.int = TRUE,   surv.median.line = "hv",   palette = "jco",   xlab = "Time [Months]",   legend.labs = c("Comparator", "Exposure of interest")   )

previous_headings: Simulation of covariates and exposure > Simulate time-to-event
title: Data generation
text: adjusting, simulated data results following hazard ratio (HR) estimates
code: cox_lhs <- "survival::Surv(eventtime, status)" cox_rhs <- paste(colnames(sim_covar), collapse = " + ") cox_form = as.formula(paste(cox_lhs, "~ exposure +", cox_rhs))    cox_fit <- survival::coxph(cox_form, data = sim_df)  cox_fit %>%    gtsummary::tbl_regression(exponentiate = T)

title: Data generation
text: provide flexibility play complete data introducing missingness, offer two datasets: smdi_data_complete: complete data smdi_data: data certain covariates missing (see next chapter)
code: smdi_data_complete <- sim_df usethis::use_data(smdi_data_complete, overwrite = TRUE)

title: Data generation
text: many different quantitative disciplines classic epidemiology machine deep learning increasing interest utilizing electronic health records (EHR) develop prognostic/predictive models study comparative effectiveness safety medical interventions. Especially information variables readily available datasets (e.g.¬†administrative claims) high interest, including vital signs, biomarkers lab data. However, covariates often just partially observed various reasons: Physician simply perform/order certain test Certain measurements just collected particularly sick patients Information ‚Äòhiding‚Äô unstructured records, e.g.¬†clinical notes illustrate smdi's main functionalities using dataset, introduce missingness relevant covariates (see table @ref(overview)) critical confounders causal exposure-outcome relationship smdi_data dataset. order introduce missingness following different missingness mechanisms, use ampute function mice package. excellent tutorial flexible elegant function can found . brief, introduce missingness ‚Ä¶ Determining missingess pattern Creating weight vector, using fitted linear models probability observations becoming missing Specifying type logistic probabillity distribution missingness weights Defining overall missingness proportion
code: # prepare a placeholder df for missing simulation # we do not consider ses_cat tmp <- smdi_data_complete %>%    dplyr::select(-c(ses_cat))  # determine missingness pattern template miss_pattern <- rep(1, ncol(tmp))

title: Data generation
text: ecog_cat1 set missing according following specification: Missingness pattern: ecog_cat set missing Weight vector: weights, since missingness dependent observed unobserved covariates Type: applicable : insert DAG missingness-confounder relationship
code: # specify missingness pattern # (0 = set to missing, 1 = remains complete) mcar_col <- which(colnames(tmp)=="ecog_cat") miss_pattern_mcar <- replace(miss_pattern, mcar_col, 0)  miss_prop_mcar <- .3  set.seed(42) smdi_data_mcar <- mice::ampute(   data = tmp,   prop = miss_prop_mcar,   mech = "MCAR",   patterns = miss_pattern_mcar,   bycases = TRUE   )$amp %>%    dplyr::select(ecog_cat)  smdi_data_mcar %>%    dplyr::select(ecog_cat) %>%    dplyr::mutate(ecog_cat = forcats::fct_na_value_to_level(factor(ecog_cat), level = "missing")) %>%    gtsummary::tbl_summary()

title: Data generation
text: egfr_cat set missing according following specification: Missingness pattern: egfr_cat set missing Weight vector: covariates (except egfr_cat ses_cat) contribute equal weights linear predictors probability observations becoming missing Type: higher weighted sum scores (.e.¬†higher odds egfr_cat mutation) larger probability becoming incomplete Define overall missingness proportion ~20%
code: # specify missingness pattern # (0 = set to missing, 1 = remains complete) mar_col <- which(colnames(tmp)=="egfr_cat") miss_pattern_mar <- replace(miss_pattern, mar_col, 0)  # weights to compute missingness probability  # by assigning a non-zero value miss_weights_mar <- rep(1, ncol(tmp)) miss_weights_mar <- replace(miss_weights_mar, mar_col, 0)  miss_prop_mar <- .2  set.seed(42) smdi_data_mar <- mice::ampute(   data = tmp,   prop = miss_prop_mar,   mech = "MAR",   patterns = miss_pattern_mar,   weights = miss_weights_mar,   bycases = TRUE,   type = "RIGHT"   )$amp  smdi_data_mar %>%    dplyr::select(egfr_cat) %>%    dplyr::mutate(egfr_cat = forcats::fct_na_value_to_level(factor(egfr_cat), level = "missing")) %>%   gtsummary::tbl_summary()

title: Data generation
text: Missingness pattern: pdl1_num set missing Weight vector: pdl1_num (non-zero value) linear predictor probability observations becoming missing Type: Specify type logistic probabillity distribution missingness weights, cases low weighted sum scores (.e.¬†lower pdl1_num expression) larger probability becoming incomplete Define overall missingness proportion ~40%
code: # determine missingness pattern mnar_v_col <- which(colnames(tmp)=="pdl1_num") miss_pattern <- rep(1, ncol(tmp)) miss_pattern_mnar_v <- replace(miss_pattern, mnar_v_col, 0)  # weights to compute missingness probability  # by assigning a non-zero value # MNAR_v: covariate itself is only predictor miss_weights_mnar_v <- rep(0, ncol(tmp)) miss_weights_mnar_v <- replace(miss_weights_mnar_v, mnar_v_col, 1)  miss_prop_mnar_v <- .4  set.seed(42) smdi_data_mnar_v <- mice::ampute(   data = tmp,   prop = miss_prop_mnar_v,   mech = "MNAR",   patterns = miss_pattern_mnar_v,   weights = miss_weights_mnar_v,   bycases = TRUE,   type = "LEFT"   )$amp  smdi_data_mnar_v %>%    dplyr::select(pdl1_num) %>%    gtsummary::tbl_summary()

title: Data generation
code: smdi_data <- smdi_data_complete %>%    dplyr::select(-c(ecog_cat, egfr_cat, pdl1_num)) %>%    dplyr::bind_cols(ecog_cat = smdi_data_mcar$ecog_cat, egfr_cat = smdi_data_mar$egfr_cat, pdl1_num = smdi_data_mnar_v$pdl1_num) %>%    mutate(across(ends_with("cat"), as.factor))

title: Data generation
text: Let‚Äôs look final dataset.
code: smdi_data %>%    gtsummary::tbl_summary(by = "exposure") %>%    gtsummary::add_overall() %>%    gtsummary::add_difference()

title: Data generation
text: Exporting data data/, can used educative purposes playing around package.
code: usethis::use_data(smdi_data, overwrite = TRUE)

title: NARFCS sensitivity analysis
text: seen earlier, missingness mechanism important covariate, strong partially observed confounder, truly follows either missing completely random (MCAR) missing random value (MNAR[value]) scenario, distinction two can turn difficult. can serious consequences since covariates follow true MNAR(value) mechanism may severely bias effect estimation exposure interest. reality, able know 100% true missingness mechanism may always residual uncertainty case MNAR(value). positive side, however, Leacy Moreno-Betancur et al.1 proposed useful procedure impute multivariable missing data MNAR(value) conditions. definition, MNAR(value) mechanism, true (unobserved) values variable systematically differ observed values. idea random fully conditional specification (NARFCS) sensitivity analysis specify imputation model containing sensitivity parameter ùõÖ reflects systematic departure missing random (MAR) mechanism.

title: NARFCS sensitivity analysis
text: example, age_num patients certain age cut-may systematically less frequently recorded. Despite , age_num may still important predictor initiation treatment interest simultaneously import prognostic variable outcome (time death due reason [overall survival] example). simplicity, don‚Äôt assume missing covariates now. order introduce MNAR(value) mechanism age_num covariate, : Determine missingess pattern, age_num set missing Create weight vector, age_num (non-zero value) linear predictor probability observations becoming missing Specify type logistic probabillity distribution missingness weights, cases low weighted sum scores (.e.¬†younger age_num) larger probability becoming incomplete Define overall missingness proportion ~40%
code: # load complete dataset smdi_data_complete <- smdi::smdi_data_complete %>%    fastDummies::dummy_columns(     select_columns = "ses_cat",     remove_most_frequent_dummy = TRUE,     remove_selected_columns = TRUE     )  # determine missingness pattern age_col <- which(colnames(smdi_data_complete)=="age_num") miss_pattern <- rep(1, ncol(smdi_data_complete)) miss_pattern_age <- replace(miss_pattern, age_col, 0)  # weights to compute missingness probability # covariate itself is only predictor miss_weights_mnar_v <- rep(0, ncol(smdi_data_complete)) miss_weights_mnar_v <- replace(miss_weights_mnar_v, age_col, 1)  miss_prop_age <- .3  set.seed(42) smdi_data_mnar_v <- mice::ampute(   data = smdi_data_complete,   prop = miss_prop_age,   mech = "MNAR",   patterns = miss_pattern_age,   weights = miss_weights_mnar_v,   bycases = TRUE,   type = "LEFT"   )$amp

title: NARFCS sensitivity analysis
text: plot direct comparison age_num distributions original data data complete cases removing missing value following MNAR(value) mechanism, can observe systematic difference two datasets.
code: # plot dplyr::bind_rows(   smdi_data_complete %>% dplyr::select(age_num) %>% dplyr::mutate(dataset = "Complete"),   smdi_data_mnar_v %>% dplyr::select(age_num) %>% dplyr::mutate(dataset = "MNAR(value)")   ) %>%    ggplot2::ggplot(ggplot2::aes(x = dataset, y = age_num)) +   ggplot2::geom_violin() +   ggplot2::geom_boxplot(width = 0.3) +   ggplot2::stat_summary(     fun = "mean",     geom = "pointrange",     color = "red"       ) +   ggplot2::labs(     y = "Age [years]",     x = "Cohort"   ) +   ggplot2::theme_bw()

title: NARFCS sensitivity analysis
text: can now compare estimate bias caused 40% MNAR(value) missing values. First, specify general outcome model. Next, compute true Hazard Ratio (HR), complete case HR standard mice multiple imputation HR.  can observe, multiple imputation approach led wrong conclusion
code: # outcome model (see data generation script) cox_lhs <- "survival::Surv(eventtime, status)" covariates <- smdi_data_complete %>%    dplyr::select(-c(exposure, eventtime, status)) %>%    names()  cox_rhs <- paste(covariates, collapse = " + ") cox_form <- as.formula(paste(cox_lhs, "~ exposure +", cox_rhs))  cox_form   #> survival::Surv(eventtime, status) ~ exposure + age_num + female_cat +  #>     ecog_cat + smoking_cat + physical_cat + egfr_cat + alk_cat +  #>     pdl1_num + histology_cat + copd_cat + ses_cat_1_low + ses_cat_2_middle # true outcome model cox_fit_true <- survival::coxph(cox_form, data = smdi_data_complete) %>%    broom::tidy(exponentiate = TRUE, conf.int = TRUE) %>%    dplyr::filter(term == "exposure") %>%    dplyr::select(term, estimate, conf.low, conf.high, std.error) %>%    dplyr::mutate(analysis = "True estimate")   # complete case analysis cox_fit_cc <- survival::coxph(cox_form, data = smdi_data_mnar_v) %>%    broom::tidy(exponentiate = TRUE, conf.int = TRUE) %>%    dplyr::filter(term == "exposure") %>%    dplyr::select(term, estimate, conf.low, conf.high, std.error) %>%    dplyr::mutate(analysis = "Complete case analysis")  # Multiple imputation (predictive mean matching) cox_fit_imp <- mice::mice(   data = smdi_data_mnar_v,   seed = 42,    print = FALSE   ) %>%   with(     expr = survival::coxph(formula(paste(format(cox_form), collapse = "")))     ) %>%    mice::pool() %>%    summary(conf.int = TRUE, exponentiate = TRUE) %>%    dplyr::filter(term == "exposure") %>%    dplyr::select(term, estimate, conf.low = `2.5 %`, conf.high = `97.5 %`, std.error) %>%    dplyr::mutate(analysis = "Multiple imputation")  forest <- dplyr::bind_rows(cox_fit_true, cox_fit_cc, cox_fit_imp) %>%    dplyr::mutate(analysis = factor(analysis, levels = c("True estimate", "Complete case analysis", "Multiple imputation"))) %>%    ggplot2::ggplot(ggplot2::aes(y = forcats::fct_rev(analysis))) +   ggplot2::geom_point(ggplot2::aes(x = estimate), shape = 15, size = 3) +   ggplot2::geom_errorbar(ggplot2::aes(xmin = conf.low, xmax = conf.high)) +   ggplot2::geom_vline(xintercept = 1, linetype = "dashed") +   ggplot2::labs(x = "Hazard ratio (95% CI)", y= "") +   ggplot2::theme_bw()  table <- dplyr::bind_rows(cox_fit_true, cox_fit_cc, cox_fit_imp) %>%    dplyr::select(-term) %>%    dplyr::relocate(analysis, .before = estimate) %>%    dplyr::mutate(dplyr::across(tidyselect::where(is.numeric), ~round(.x, 2)))  gridExtra::grid.arrange(gridExtra::tableGrob(table, rows = NULL), forest)

title: NARFCS sensitivity analysis
text: mentioned , true (unobserved) values variable systematically differ observed values difference reflected sensitivity parameter ùõÖ. specifically, interpretation ùõÖ difference distribution missing observed age_num values conditional covariates. Hence, continuous covariates (like example) difference mean conditional female_cat + ecog_cat + smoking_cat + physical_cat + egfr_cat + alk_cat + pdl1_num + histology_cat + copd_cat + ses_cat_1_low + ses_cat_2_middle. Since data generation model specifiy interactions relationships covariates, can simplify little just take crude difference means. reality, know sensitivity parameter, easily plug NARFCS.
code: # compute the conditional mean difference in age  # between dataset with complete observations # and dataset with partially observed age covariate lm_form <- as.formula(paste("age_num ~ complete_dataset + exposure + ", paste(covariates[-1], collapse = "+")))  data_combined <- rbind(   smdi_data_complete %>% dplyr::mutate(complete_dataset = 1),    smdi_data_mnar_v %>% dplyr::mutate(complete_dataset = 0)   )  cond_mean_diff <- stats::lm(lm_form, data = data_combined)$coefficients[["complete_dataset"]] cond_mean_diff #> [1] -3.224786

title: NARFCS sensitivity analysis
text: unfortunately, reality usually don‚Äôt know value ùõÖ. Nevertheless, want make sure whatever analytical decision chose primary analysis (complete case approach imputation approach), results drastically change true underlying missingness mechanism MNAR(value). NARFCS sensitivity analysis comes handy also often used tipping point analysis, .e.¬†model multiple NARFCS-specified imputation models range realistic ùõÖ sensitivity parameters evaluate pre-specified ùõÖ, confidence interval cross certain estimate threshold discard global conclusion primary analysis. Based tipping point analysis, figured systematic departure age_num MAR may likely main anlysis, suggesting primary analysis estimates exposure likely biased random value (MNAR[value]) missingness age_num.
code: # initialize method vector method_vector <- rep("", ncol(smdi_data_mnar_v))  # columns for narfcs imputation with sensitivity parameter mnar_imp_method <- which(colnames(smdi_data_mnar_v) == "age_num")  # update method vector method_vector <- replace(x = method_vector, list = c(mnar_imp_method), values = c("mnar.norm"))  # modeled over a range of deltas narfcs_modeled <- function(i){      # mnar model specification ('i' is delta parameter)   mnar_blot <- list(age_num = list(ums = paste(i)))    narfcs_imp <- mice::mice(     data = smdi_data_mnar_v,     method = method_vector,     blots = mnar_blot,     seed = 42,      print = FALSE     ) %>%      with(       expr = survival::coxph(formula(paste(format(cox_form), collapse = "")))       ) %>%      mice::pool() %>%      summary(conf.int = TRUE, exponentiate = TRUE) %>%      dplyr::filter(term == "exposure") %>%      dplyr::select(term, estimate, conf.low = `2.5 %`, conf.high = `97.5 %`, std.error) %>%      dplyr::mutate(delta = i)    }   narfcs_range <- lapply(   X = seq(-25, 25, 1),   FUN = narfcs_modeled   )  narfcs_range_df <- do.call(rbind, narfcs_range)  reference_lines <- tibble::tibble(   yintercept = c(cox_fit_true[[2]]),   Reference = c("TRUE HR"),   color = c("darkgreen")   )  narfcs_range_df %>%    ggplot2::ggplot(ggplot2::aes(x = delta, y = estimate)) +   ggplot2::geom_point() +   ggplot2::geom_line() +   ggplot2::geom_ribbon(ggplot2::aes(ymin = conf.low, ymax = conf.high), alpha = 0.15) +   ggplot2::labs(x = "Sensitivity parameter Œ¥", y = "Hazard ratio (95% CI)") +   ggplot2::scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(-25, 25, 2), limits = c(-25, 25)) +   ggplot2::scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(0.6, 1.2, 0.1), limits = c(0.6, 1.2)) +   ggplot2::geom_hline(ggplot2::aes(yintercept = yintercept, color = Reference), reference_lines) +   ggplot2::scale_colour_manual(values = reference_lines$color) +   ggplot2::theme_bw() +   ggplot2::theme(legend.position="top")

title: NARFCS sensitivity analysis
text: Now, can missing smdi_data dataset. However, gets little tricky since multiple missing covariates, follow different missingness mechanisms. quick overview missing variables using smdi_summarize() function. Alternatively, can use smdi_vis().
code: smdi::smdi_data %>%    smdi::smdi_summarize() #> # A tibble: 3 √ó 3 #>   covariate n_miss perc_miss #>   <chr>      <int> <chr>     #> 1 pdl1_num     971 38.84%    #> 2 ecog_cat     786 31.44%    #> 3 egfr_cat     536 21.44% smdi::smdi_data %>%    smdi::smdi_vis(top_n_covar = 3)

title: NARFCS sensitivity analysis
text: NARFCS procedure comes mice package provides flexibility execute NARFCS procedure presence partially observed covariates may assumed missing random. Given smdi_diagnose analysis, hypothesize pdl1_num may MNAR(value). plausible context pdl1_num cell staining percentage patients tested showed lower PD-L1 staining levels less likely tested future. Despite , pdl1_num still important predictor initiation treatment interest simultaneously import prognostic variable outcome (time death due reason [overall survival].2 Hence, decide run tipping point sensitivity analysis imputing pdl1_num range ùõÖ sensitivity parameters imputing ecog_cat egfr_cat ‚Äúnormal‚Äù imputation model.  can see, also pdl1_num sensitive departures MAR small, realistic ùõÖ sensitivity parameter values.
code: # we one hot encode the `ses_cat` variable again  # in the smdi_data dataset smdi_data <- smdi::smdi_data %>%    fastDummies::dummy_columns(     select_columns = "ses_cat",     remove_most_frequent_dummy = TRUE,     remove_selected_columns = TRUE     )  # initialize method vector method_vector <- rep("", ncol(smdi_data))  # specify columns for narfcs and 'normal' imputation pdl1_mnar_col <- which(colnames(smdi_data) == "pdl1_num") ecog_mar_col <- which(colnames(smdi_data) == "ecog_cat") egfr_mnar_col <- which(colnames(smdi_data) == "egfr_cat")  # update method vector method_vector <- replace(   x = method_vector,    list = c(pdl1_mnar_col, ecog_mar_col, egfr_mnar_col),    values = c("mnar.norm", "logreg", "logreg")   )  # modeled over a range of deltas narfcs_modeled <- function(i){      # mnar model specification for pdl1_num ('i' is delta parameter)   mnar_blot <- list(pdl1_num = list(ums = paste(i)))    narfcs_imp <- mice::mice(     data = smdi_data,     method = method_vector,     blots = mnar_blot,     seed = 42,      print = FALSE     ) %>%     with(       expr = survival::coxph(formula(paste(format(cox_form), collapse = "")))       ) %>%     mice::pool() %>%     summary(conf.int = TRUE, exponentiate = TRUE) %>%     dplyr::filter(term == "exposure") %>%     dplyr::select(term, estimate, conf.low = `2.5 %`, conf.high = `97.5 %`, std.error) %>%     dplyr::mutate(delta = i)    }   narfcs_range <- lapply(   X = seq(-25, 25, 1),   FUN = narfcs_modeled   )  narfcs_range_df <- do.call(rbind, narfcs_range)  reference_lines <- tibble::tibble(   yintercept = c(cox_fit_true[[2]]),   Reference = c("TRUE HR"),   color = c("darkgreen")   )  narfcs_range_df %>%    ggplot2::ggplot(ggplot2::aes(x = delta, y = estimate)) +   ggplot2::geom_point() +   ggplot2::geom_line() +   ggplot2::geom_ribbon(ggplot2::aes(ymin = conf.low, ymax = conf.high), alpha = 0.15) +   ggplot2::labs(x = "Sensitivity parameter Œ¥", y = "Hazard ratio (95% CI)") +   ggplot2::scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(-25, 25, 2), limits = c(-25, 25)) +   ggplot2::scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(0.5, 1.2, 0.1), limits = c(0.5, 1.2)) +   ggplot2::geom_hline(ggplot2::aes(yintercept = yintercept, color = Reference), reference_lines) +   ggplot2::scale_colour_manual(values = reference_lines$color) +   ggplot2::theme_bw() +   ggplot2::theme(legend.position="top")

title: NARFCS sensitivity analysis
text: information helpful resources regarding sensitivity analyses missing data, recommend checking following links manuscripts: https://stefvanbuuren.name/fimd/sec-sensitivity.html https://amices.org/mice/reference/mice.impute.mnar.html https://raw.githack.com/moreno-betancur/NARFCS/master/Vignette.html Tompsett, D. M., Leacy, F., Moreno-Betancur, M., Heron, J., & White, . R. (2018). use --random fully conditional specification (NARFCS) procedure practice. Statistics Medicine, 37(15), 2338-2353. doi:10.1002/sim.7643 . Van Buuren, S., Boshuizen, H.C., Knook, D.L. (1999) Multiple imputation missing blood pressure covariates survival analysis. Statistics Medicine, 18, 681‚Äì694.

title: Computes mean/median absolute standardized mean differences between observed and missing observations ‚Äî smdi_asmd

title: Computes mean/median absolute standardized mean differences between observed and missing observations ‚Äî smdi_asmd
text: data dataframe tibble object partially observed/missing variables covar character covariate covariate vector variable/column name(s) investigate. NULL, function automatically includes columns least one missing observation remaining covariates used predictors median logical median (= TRUE; recommended default) mean absolute standardized mean differences (asmd) computed includeNA logical, missingness partially observed covariates explicitly modeled (default FALSE) ... arguments

title: Computes mean/median absolute standardized mean differences between observed and missing observations ‚Äî smdi_asmd

title: Computes mean/median absolute standardized mean differences between observed and missing observations ‚Äî smdi_asmd
text: *asmd* computed every covariate one--one jointly. multivariate missingness, .e. just one missing covariate exist, can decide happen partially observed 'predictor' covariates using `includeNA` parameter. , `includeNA` set FALSE (default), *asmd* observed cases computed, `includeNA` set TRUE, missingness modeled explicit category (categorical covariates ). behavior desired, data transformations example smdi::smdi_na_indicator function, may make sense calling function. dataframe generally consist exposure variable, outcome variable(s), partially observed covariates fully observed covariates deemed important final modeling (optionally) considered auxiliary variables. partially observed covariates provided, function automatically looks variables/columns NA (powered smdi::smdi_summarize() function) *Important*: include variables like ID variables, ZIP codes, dates, etc. Credit: Much function utilizes functionalities tableone::CreateTableOne

title: Computes mean/median absolute standardized mean differences between observed and missing observations ‚Äî smdi_asmd

title: smdi exemplary lung cancer dataset ‚Äî smdi_data
text: ## `smdi_data` data frame 2,500 rows 14 columns: exposure Treatment assignment variable (binary). Indicates initiation exposure interest (1) versus comparator regimen (0) age_num Age baseline years female_cat gender female (0 = , 1 = yes) ecog_cat ECOG performance score baseline (0 versus 1). Shows 30% missingness following MCAR mechanism. smoking_cat Smoking status baseline (0 = non-smoker, 1 = smoker) physical_cat Physical activity baseline (active versus active) egfr_cat EGFR mutation status (0 = wild-type, 1 = alteration). Shows 20% missingness following MAR mechanism. alk_cat ALK transolcation mutation status (0 = wild-type, 1 = alteration) pdl1_num PD-L1 cell staining biomarker %. Shows 40% missingness following MNAR(value) mechanism histology_cat Tumor histology (0 = nonsquamous, 1 = squamous) ses_cat Socio-economic status (multi-categorical: 1-low, 2-middle, 3-high) copd_cat COPD comorbidity baseline eventtime time censoring event status event indicator time t; 0 = censored, 1 = deceased

what: Create binary missing indicator variables by two different strategies ‚Äî smdi_na_indicator
title: Create binary missing indicator variables by two different strategies ‚Äî smdi_na_indicator
text: function takes dataframe creates binary missing indicator variable. can realized two different approaches: Approach 1 (drop_NA_col = FALSE): retains variables dataframe missing observations Approach 2 (drop_NA_col = TRUE): creates binary missing indicator variable variables missing observations drops original variables missing observations. Important: Make sure variables format correct avoid include variables like ID variables, ZIP codes, dates, etc.

title: Create binary missing indicator variables by two different strategies ‚Äî smdi_na_indicator
code: smdi_na_indicator(data = NULL, covar = NULL, drop_NA_col = TRUE)

text: data dataframe tibble object partially observed/missing variables covar character covariate covariate vector variable/column name(s) investigate. NULL, function automatically includes columns least one missing observation drop_NA_col logical, drop specified columns NA (default) retain columns

what: Wrapper of NARFCS enhanced forked mice version ‚Äî smdi_narfcs
title: Wrapper of NARFCS enhanced forked mice version ‚Äî smdi_narfcs
text: function wrapper NARFCS extension package `mice` M. Moreno-Betancur, F. Leacy, D. Tompsett . White (https://raw.githack.com/moreno-betancur/NARFCS/master/Vignette.html) function performs sensitivity analysis based Random Fully Conditional Specification (NARFCS) procedure. wrapper intends give users friendly version package, especially situations many covariates. function follows Formula syntax fully conditionally specified models. great introduction overall NARFCS procedure implementation, please visit <https://raw.githack.com/moreno-betancur/NARFCS/master/Vignette.html>

title: Wrapper of NARFCS enhanced forked mice version ‚Äî smdi_narfcs

title: Wrapper of NARFCS enhanced forked mice version ‚Äî smdi_narfcs
text: numeric, sensitivity parameter delta; can also range deltas used combination lapply data dataframe tibble object partially observed/missing variables. Ideally consists continuous binary covariates id_var character column name (patient) identifier variable covar character covariate covariate vector variable/column name(s) investigate; restricted one covariate time must continuous binary missing_indicator_var character indicating name  missing indicator variable(s) covar narfcs (optional) predictor_covar character covariate vector narfcs imputation procedure, specified takes available variables dataset n_impute integer, number imputed datasets per delta parameter value

title: smdi 0.1.0
text: Initial build website using pkgdown Added NEWS.md file track changes package. First draft smdi_vis() visually inspect missing data tables First draft smdi_summarize() serves convenient utility function
